turn.text: --if they're just interested... I mean, a Democratic legislator or city councilman who wants to be reelected I take it is interested only in one thing, people who will vote for him, and he doesn't care what their color.

So if he sees St. Mary's Church on the corner, and thinks there must be a lot of Catholics in that neighborhood, and they usually vote for me because they're a certain political party affiliation, or a State legislator who thinks, I know the synagogue of a certain kind is over there, and he really knows it, and happens by accident to tell somebody that's what he's thinking, is that now all contrary to the Constitution?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --I think if at a certain point the predominant goal is the separation of races or religions or ethnicities, if that is the tool that is used to accomplish incumbency protection, then that is constitutionally--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes, but Justice Breyer's example is different from mine.
In mine, I'm talking about making the Irish or the Poles or the Jews or the Wasps or what not happy to be together.
In his, the sole motivation is incumbency protection.
Why isn't your answer different from him from what it was for me?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --Well, I think I gave the answer on... the motivation... the motivation does not matter if the means is race or ethnicity.
This Court has said it doesn't matter what your ultimate goal is, you cannot use certain forbidden tools.
Race is forbidden by the Fourteenth Amendment to be used as a tool--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But in his example the people... St. Mary's gets in not because they're Catholics but because they're Democrats.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --Well, that's in essence--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: He knows that.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --a question of fact--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: He knows that.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --for the district court as to whether or not the predominant motivation was whether they were Democrats or whether they were blacks.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So if, in fact, the Court says they only wanted the St. Mary's Parish in there because they were Democrats, no problem on your theory.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: Again, it's a question of fact as to what--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes, but I mean, if that's what the fact finding is, that's not... that is not suspect on your theory, right?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --It is not suspect to get Democrats.

It is suspect to use race as a tool or religion as a tool to tell who is of one party affiliation or another because race is immutable and politics are not, and the use of race is so dangerous that this Court has said that it should not be used unless there is a compelling governmental interest and it is being used in a narrowly tailored way.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But Mr. Troy, this is the part of your argument that I have great difficulty grasping.
If race were used alone and nothing else, that would have been all right.

If the districts had been created so that they would be majority minority districts, and then the white incumbents were not part of the picture, so we had a district determined solely by race and not by incumbency, and not by anything else, that would be all right.
But once you intrude something that's nonrace, then it's unconstitutional.

That's the part that I don't understand, the logic of that, but you conceded, because that was the first step in the argument, that if... that the State has a goal, wants three majority minority districts, a racial goal, that's okay.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: Well, Your Honor--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Counsel, did you concede that--

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --I don't really think I conceded that.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --or did you say it would require strict scrutiny if that were the case?
I thought that was what I understood your response to be.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.
That's what I thought I said.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Have you made some other response to Justice Ginsburg that I missed?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: No, I don't think I did.
I think--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, I thought you said in the hypothetical that it would be compactness and other factors that would be in addition to race, and that's why you say that--

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --Your Honor, I think if you start out and race is your only goal, then maybe the Voting Rights Act--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --You said if the district were compact, the fact that they might have been motivated by an interest in getting two or three majority minority districts would not have invalidated the plan.
You did say that, didn't you?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --Let me explain.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I thought that's--
--Did you say that or not?
Let me find out, did you say that or not?

If they were compact districts, contiguous, nicely square in every case, but it was perfectly clear that there was a motive to get two or three majority minority districts, did you not say that would be okay?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: I don't think so.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: And if I did, perhaps I misspoke.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You did, then.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: Okay, I misspoke.
[Laughter]
I apologize.
If your goal, your dominant goal is racial, then strict scrutiny applies, okay.
Now, it may well be--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So that in--
--What does the statute require, then?

I mean, I certainly agree with you, I had understood our Constitution to prevent the use of race as a surrogate for... however good the objective may be, you can't use it, but then what does the... doesn't the Voting Rights Act, or our interpretation of it make the opposite assumption?
How am I to reconcile the two?
Doesn't it assume that in order to have what is being called here minority opportunity you need to herd minority voters together because they will all vote the same way?
Isn't that the assumption of our interpretation of the act, or of the act itself?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --I don't think so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It isn't.
Well, then, I don't--

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: I think the Voting Rights Act prohibits--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Why are they worried about creating minority... majority minority districts in order to comply with the act, then?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --I think the Department of Justice's maximization policy was hanging like a Sword of Damocles over this entire process.
They went in with the assumption... and this case is sort of Miller but without the Department of Justice playing its heavy hand.

They went in with the assumption that so long as they maximized they would be okay with the Department of Justice, and therefore they could do anything else they want, use race as a tool for purposes of incumbency protection, and that they did not have to narrowly tailor these districts to make them comport to requirements of section 2, if, indeed, section 2 is implicated.
But section 2 only requires geographically compact districts.
These are not geographically compact districts.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All right, but why, then--
--But what if they were?
--isn't your answer to Justice Stevens--
--Yes, but what if they were?
Would that make any difference?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: It seems to me if the Voting Rights Act requires you to draw these districts--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I'm just asking you, if they were compact, would that make any difference?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --If the Voting Rights Act required you to draw--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, no, no.

No, I'm just saying, in this case, if we had compact districts such as they started out with before they got into all the incumbency protection, would the case be any different in your view, and I'll give you a second question.
You can give me the answer to both.

Under the district court's reasoning, if they did create the same number of majority minority districts but they had gone back to where they had a few more Republican districts and a few less Democrat districts, as I think would make the difference, would that have been all right?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --I don't think I follow your second question.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: Sorry.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --What is the remedy that the district court is requiring?
They have to redraw the districts.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: They have to redraw the districts.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: In redrawing them, can they continue to have the same number of majority minority districts but differently shaped?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: Your Honor, we do not think that under the Voting Rights Act they can create single race majority districts here because the communities in question do not live in a sufficiently geographically compact area to require drawing of single race majority districts, and that is what they tried to do here.
They set out to draw single race majority districts.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Can you answer the first question that Justice Stevens asked?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And the reason... the reason is, at least I break this question into two parts, or maybe three, and to get to an answer I have to have your opinion on just his first question, which was, if these were compact, and drawn to comply with section 2, and race was used... of course, section 2 is about race... wouldn't that be a compelling interest?
I agree that Justice O'Connor says under Miller it's a compelling interest.
Would that not be a compelling interest?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: Oh, yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: We believe that if section 2--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
So you then do concede--

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --Absolutely.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --which is what I thought at the beginning--

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: If section 2 required these districts to be--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --All right.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So if they're drawing them now in order to comply with section 2--
--Why do you concede that, counsel?
[Laughter]
The Court has never held that compliance with the Voting Rights Act is a compelling State interest.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: That is true, the Court has never held that, but--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: May I ask you an alternative--
--I think he's finishing answering my question.
Oh, I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --We believe that in trying to have the State avoid the horns of a dilemma, a dilemma which, by the way, we think they falsely posit because they overinterpret the Voting Rights Act in far too broad a way, but we think that if you interpret the Voting Rights Act in a constitutional way to say that it simply prohibits discriminatory packing and cracking, then avoiding discriminatory packing and cracking can be a compelling governmental interest.

But it turns upon, Your Honor, how you interpret the Voting Rights Act, and we think that certainly if the State sought to comply with their interpretation, or with the Department of Justice's maximization policy, then it would never be... it could not be a compelling governmental interest, so it depends upon how you interpret the Voting Rights Act.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All right, may I go back to the Miller definition.
I understood you to say a moment ago that if the motive was simply to create a majority minority district, and we didn't know anything more than that, that that would, in fact, be unconstitutional.
Now let me add something to what we know.

Let us assume that in creating that majority minority district, number 1, the motive was to comply with the Voting Rights Act, and number 2, that in fact the district shape that came out of that process was a shape which was consistent with the shape that traditionally gets arrived at in districts when traditional districting practices are followed, as, for example, in Justice Stevens' case, it is a compact district.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: It--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: If that is... if those three facts are what we know, is it fair to say under the Miller definition of what is a subordination of districting to race, that we would not have an apparent case of subordinated districting to race?
That would be okay under the Miller definition, and it would not trigger strict scrutiny.
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --If you start out and your goal is to create... it seems to me that you can't really have it both ways.

If you want to say, we are going to draw remedial districts to comply with the Voting Rights Act, then you're almost by definition, I believe, going to be in strict scrutiny, because you are using race for a remedial purpose.
Then the question--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Then what happens if... let's assume... all right, if I take that example, then it seems to me I am varying Miller, because Miller didn't say that any use of race, whether for compliance of section 2 or any other, is wrong.
Miller says it's only wrong when it is subordinated to traditional districting practices.
Miller puts a limitation on it, and it seems to me that your answers to us do not recognize that limitation, so that if we were to agree with you, the Court would have to expand Miller.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --I think, Your Honor, that if you set out to create a racial goal, and your goal is to comply with the Voting Rights Act, and that is a remedial statute, and your purpose in complying with it is remedial, then it seems to me that your overwhelming purpose, because we're talking about the use of race here, must be remedial, and that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: All right--
--It depends on what Miller means by subordinated.
I suppose one could say that if you start out with objection number 1 to create a majority minority district, that is your primary goal.
Everything else, even though you follow other criteria, could be regarded as subordinated to that.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --That--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So that's your starting point.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --I think that's right, that is your starting point.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All right, but that's not what Miller says, is it?

Miller says that it's predominant if it subordinates traditional districting practices to race, and I think what you're saying is, whenever you start out with the motive of creating a majority minority district, you in fact trigger strict scrutiny, and by definition you have always... you have subordinated every other consideration to race.
Is that your answer?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: If you start out with--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I think that's what you're saying.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: If you start out with the goal--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So isn't it--

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --of accomplishing race, and you use race as... at all times to make sure... abandoning compactness, abandoning requirements of the Voting Rights Act--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --No, no, no, let's assume you don't abandon them.
You end up with a compact... we get into court.
The redistricting is done.
You've got a compact district.
It goes back to Justice Stevens' question.
The traditional districting principles have, in fact, apparently been honored here.
Strict scrutiny or not?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --Strict scrutiny.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So I think... is it fair to say, then--

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: If race was the predominant factor in drawing--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Oh, I grant you that.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --strict scrutiny.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Is it fair to say, then, that you are in fact asking us to recognize a cause of action which is broader than Miller recognized, because otherwise that language in Miller did not mean what it said.
It was in fact a misspeaking by the Court.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: I think, Your Honor, if race is the predominant motivation, and you look--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but that's the question.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Miller says, in deciding whether it is predominant or not, you look to whether it has excluded the application of traditional districting principles.

If it hasn't excluded it, then either it isn't predominant, or you've got a pretty tough row to hoe to show that it is, and you're saying, never mind whether the result is consistent with traditional districting principles or not, and that's why I say I think you're asking us to expand on Miller.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: I don't think so, Your Honor, because Miller talks about the indirect and the direct evidence, and in this case--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, I guess you don't have that here, do you?
I thought the finding was these districts did not follow normal compactness and, indeed, are quite irregular, so you don't have the hypothetical here, I assume.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --That is certainly true, Your Honor.

Texas tries to say that their only districting principle ever has been incumbency protection, and the district court found as a matter of fact that Texas had traditionally adhered to and followed other traditional districting principles and it had, in fact, abandoned compactness.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The three judges of the district court were all Texas judges here?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: They were all Texas judges.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: The thing I wonder about the particular finding on page 65a is, I've got the point that if these were compact maybe you apply strict scrutiny, that section 2 perhaps we'd agree would justify it.

If they depart from the compactness solely for nonracial reasons, I think we agree, but I'm not certain, that solely for nonracial reasons it would be okay, and then the question is, what did they do here, and what he says is, in order to protect incumbents other African American voters were deliberately fenced out.

But what it doesn't say is whether those African American voters were fenced out because they were African Americans or because there was an inference about their voting behavior in respect to one incumbent or another--

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: If I--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --and wouldn't that be key as to why they were fenced out, just as you've said you might have Jews in a district knowing that they're Jews and likely to vote Democrat, and you say okay, that's all right, if the reason is that they're likely to vote Democrat, and isn't this silent as to what the reason that the African American voters were or were not fenced out?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --Your Honor, in this case the African American and the Hispanic communities in Harris County were simply pulled apart for their own sake.
That is what the district court found.
They were pulled apart because the Hispanic community said, we want our own district, and we don't care about Gingles, we don't care about compactness, we want our own district.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Troy, I didn't understand you to say what Justice Breyer just said.
Maybe you agree with him.
I didn't understand you to say that you could include, let's say Jews in a district because you know that Jews will vote Democratic.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: In fact, I did not say that.
I said you cannot--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I thought you said just the opposite.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --In fact, I did.
I said that neither race nor religion may be used as a proxy for determining political affiliation.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So then that means you do favor, or somebody could bring a lawsuit in any kind of city council election, any of the thousands of elections in the United States and try to show that what the council had in mind was, it... all it knew was, this is an Irish neighborhood, this is a Catholic neighborhood, this is a some other neighborhood, and we're only interested in whether they vote Democrat or Republican, but if you could show that's in the councilman's mind at the time and he's making that inference, all this would become unconstitutional, thrown into the Federal courts, et cetera.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: The reason why I don't think that's going to happen, Your Honor, is because of compactness, contiguity, respect for political subdivision.

What I understand what happens in city councils throughout the country is they take a look at particular neighborhoods, particular areas of interest, where people have things in common like the schools they go to, the places they shop, the water supply, the potholes in the streets.
What they did in this case was, they abandoned that and they said we are going to, particularly in Harris County, we're going to separate the races.

We're going to take someone who lived in the northwest corner of the city and who's always voted in District 18, who's Hispanic, we're going to take Al Vera and we're going to lump him with the Hispanics in the southwest... in the southeastern part of the city because he is Hispanic.
That seems to me to not respect traditional principles and to be affirmatively unconstitutional.

And Your Honors, in Texas what the court found, in Dallas what the court found is that simply, there was capitulation to a demand by the Dallas black community that... I'm quoting the Department of Justice's narrative, the narrative to the Department of Justice.
This is what Texas told the Department of Justice, that
"the Dallas black community insisted that a safe black district be drawn that had a total black population of at least 50 percent. "
That's at the joint appendix at 106.

Your Honors, we've gotten off on the... because we've been entertaining hypotheticals we've gotten far away from what happened in this case, and what happened in this case was that race was used as a tool for incumbency protection only secondarily.
Primarily, there was this maximization policy of the Department of Justice that everybody knew about.

They... Eddie Bernice Johnson specifically said, my policy was, if it could be drawn it must be drawn, and all other concerns were subordinated to that, and so that is what happened here, and that, we submit, is unconstitutional.
If there are no further questions--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I have one if you do have a minute left.

Supposing you started out with three compact districts that were contiguous, and race was one of the reasons for drawing them that way, but if you drew them that way, the Democrats were in control, they found they would create a few more Republican seats than they wanted to, so they redrew them with squiggles to get more Democrat seats... forget about incumbents, just party politics, simply... would that be a permissible reason to do it, in your view?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would that be a permissible reason to redraw and get unattractive districts in order to protect the number of Democrats, as opposed to the number of incumbents?

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: I'm not quite sure I caught your first hypothetical, and my time is up, but I'd be happy if the Chief Justice will permit me to--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Just go ahead and answer.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --The first part--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The hypothetical is that you start with compact districts that you would say would barely pass muster, even though race was an important factor in picking them up, but you get into noncompactness and gerrymandering in districts like this not to protect incumbents as such, but to make sure that the Republicans, who do not control the legislature, won't get too many seats.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --I think if your motivations are political, then your motivations are political.
If your motivations are racial, your motivations are racial, and if your motivations are--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The question is whether a political motivation would be a justification.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --Political... for noncompactness?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: It can be, yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I think he's asking for noncompactness on the basis of race.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: Noncompactness on the basis of race, no.
If it's noncompactness... if--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, look, your time is up.

turn.speaker: daniel_e_troy
turn.label: Mr. Daniel E. Troy
turn.text: --If there are just whites, and it's just a Democrat, and you jiggle the lines, that's okay.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I think you've answered the question, Mr. Troy.
The case is submitted.
